THE VISION OF WILLIAM CONCERNING ‚ÄúPERS THE PLOUHMON.‚Äù The Vernon Text; or Text A. Square brackets denote editorial insertions or emendations. [Prologus.] In a somer sesun whon softe was √æe sonne, I schop me in-to a schroud A scheep as I were; In Habite of an Hermite vn-holy of werkes, Wende I wydene in √æis world wondres to here. Bote in a Mayes Morwnynge on Maluerne hulles Me bi-fel a ferly A Feyrie me √æouhte; I was weori of wandringe and wente me to reste Vndur a brod banke bi a Bourne syde, And as I lay and leonede and lokede on √æe watres, I slumberde in A slepyng hit sownede so murie. √ûenne gon I Meeten A Meruelous sweuene, √ûat I was in A Wildernesse wuste I neuer where, And as I beo-heold in-to √æe Est an-hei? to √æe sonne, I sauh a Tour on A Toft [tri?ely] I-maket; A Deop Dale bi-neo√æe A dungun √æer-Inne, With deop dich and derk and dredful of siht. A Feir feld ful of folk fond I √æer bi-twene, Of alle maner of men √æe mene and √æe riche, Worchinge and wondringe as √æe world aske√æ. Summe putten hem to √æe plou? and pleiden hem ful seldene, In Eringe and in Sowynge swonken ful harde, √ûat monie of √æeos wasturs In Glotonye distruen. And summe putten hem to pruide apparaylden hem √æer-after, In Cuntinaunce of clo√æinge queinteliche de-Gyset; To preyere and to penaunce putten heom monye, For loue of vr lord liueden ful harde, In Hope for to haue Heuene-riche blisse; As Ancres and Hermytes √æat holde√æ hem in heore Celles, Coueyte not in Cuntre to carien a-boute, For non likerous lyflode heore licam to plese. And summe chosen Chaffare to cheeuen √æe bettre, As hit seme√æ to vre siht √æat suche men scholden; And summe Mur√æhes to maken as Munstrals cunne, [And gete gold wi√æ here gle giltles, I trowe.] Bote Iapers and Iangelers Iudas Children, Founden hem Fantasyes and fooles hem maaden, And habbe√æ wit at heor wille to worchen ?if hem luste. √ûat Poul preche√æ of hem I dar not preouen heere; Qui loquitur turpiloquium Hee is Luciferes hyne. Bidders and Beggers faste a-boute eoden, Til heor Bagges and heore Balies weren [bratful] I-crommet; Feyneden hem for heore foode fou?ten atte alle; In Glotonye, God wot gon heo to Bedde, And ryseth vp wi√æ ribaudye √æis Roberdes knaues; Sleep and Sleu?√æe suwe√æ hem euere. Pilgrimes and Palmers Plihten hem to-gederes For to seche seint Ieme and seintes at Roome; Wenten for√æ in heore wey with mony wyse tales, And hedden leue to ly?en al heore lyf [aftir]. [Ermytes on an hep wi√æ hokide staues, Wenten to Walsyngham & here wenchis aftir;] Grete lobres and longe √æat lo√æ weore to swynke Clo√æeden hem in Copes to beo knowen for bre√æeren; And summe schopen [hem] to hermytes heore ese to haue. I Font √æere Freres all √æe Foure Ordres, Prechinge √æe peple for profyt of heore wombes, Glosynge √æe Gospel as hem good like√æ, For Couetyse of Copes Construe√æ hit ille; For monye of √æis Maistres mowen clo√æen hem at lyking, For Moneye and heore Marchaundie meeten ofte to-gedere. Se√æ√æe charite ha√æ be chapmon [and] cheef to schriuen lordes, Mony ferlyes han bi-falle in a fewe ?eres. But holychirche bi-ginne holde bet to-gedere, √ûe moste Mischeef on molde mounte√æ vp faste. √ûer prechede a pardoner as he a prest were, And brou?t vp a Bulle with Bisschopes seles, And seide √æat him-self mihte a-soylen hem alle Of Falsnesse and Fastinge and of vouwes I-broken. √ûe lewede Men likede him wel and leeue√æ his speche, And comen vp knelynge and cusseden his Bulle; He bonchede hem with his Breuet and blered heore ei?en, And rauhte with his Ragemon Ringes and Broches. √ûus ?e ?iue√æ oure gold Glotonye to helpen, And leue√æ hit to losels √æat lecherie haunten. Weore √æe Bisschop I-blesset and wor√æ bo√æe his Eres, Heo scholde not beo so hardi to deceyue so √æe peple. A louely ladi on leor In linnene I-clo√æed, Com a-doun from √æe [clyf] and clepte me feire, And seide, ‚Äúsone! slepest √æou?
